fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Barclays to net £250m from FirstCaribbean sale Barclays is selling its stake in FirstCaribbean International Bank, despite its ambition to increase profits from overseas. It stands to make £250m from the sale of 90% of its holding to Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. CIBC is buying 43% of FirstCaribbean from Barclays, which has been in the region since the 1920s. FirstCaribbean has operations in 17 countries including Antigua, Barbados, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago. Barclays no longer regards its stake in FirstCaribbean, which it bought it 2001, as central and plans to expand in other areas. Its shares rose 5.5p to 735p. Jill Treanor Aviva leads the way with plans to go carbon neutral Aviva, Britain's biggest insurance group, will become the first insurer to try to make its operations throughout the world carbon neutral. The parent company of Norwich Union, which is the world's fifth-largest insurance group and has operations in 25 countries, announced yesterday that by the end of the first quarter of 2007 it will have offset 110,000 tonnes of carbon, the amount it estimates to have emitted this year. Richard Harvey, group chief executive, said: "We believe climate change to be the most important environmental issue facing the world." Angela Balakrishnan Apple falls on allegations of stock option inquiry Shares of Apple Computer fell almost 5% yesterday morning after reports that federal prosecutors were investigating whether former company executives forged documents to maximise stock option profits. The Recorder, a San Francisco-based publication owned by American Lawyer Media, cited people with knowledge of the case who requested anonymity because the case is the subject of criminal and civil government investigations. Apple said the company was providing the US securities and exchange commission with the results of its internal investigation. Associated Press New York
